--- kstanley@... wrote:
> Darren can correct me if I'm wrong, but if I recall
> correctly this
> solution was accidentally evolved with recurrency
> turned off!  In
> other words, NEAT was forced to solve the problem
> without recurrent
> connections.  That may sound impossible, but
> actually it explains why
> there are so many nodes.   The "chains" of nodes act
> like a memory,
> because it takes several steps for activation to
> travel all the way
> down the chain, so it is able to effectively store
> information from
> the past that does not come to the outputs for
> several iterations.  If
> I am right about this, this architecture is actually
> somewhat
> remarkable, since it implements a kind of "memory"
> that is hardly ever
> discussed when people talk about NN's.

In the usual feed-forward network, the MLP, updating
starts with the inputs and proceeds forward until the
outputs are updated.  Hence the new input values
completely determine all values throughout the net,
obliterating any memory.  

A memory such as you describe would occur if you first
updated the outputs, and then proceeded backward,
finally updating the input layer last.

Does the latter occur in NEAT?  How does NEAT decide
when to update each neuron?
